text: I like perspective's klick funnels. They're a German SaaS start-up offering a tool for building your own mobile optimized, interactive websites. There are a few English language samples on their website here: <https://perspective.co/en/case-studies/>

attachments.title: Perspective Case Studies: Yes, these companies are super successful...now
attachments.text: "I wish I'd built my company with Perspective Funnels from the ground up..." – most of our customers are saying. Just imagine what would've been...

text:
Hi Olivia! Welcome to the content community. You may be a newb, but you're already asking great questions and are thinking high-level strategy. Some of this stuff may be included as subpoints within the points you mentioned, but when it comes to blogs, specifically, here are some other items we think about when planning and drafting blogs:
• How do blogs fit into larger marketing campaigns? 
• To that end, where do these blogs fit into the funnel? Most of the time, it's awareness-level, but sometimes they can go into that MOFU phase. 
• Where/how will we promote the blogs (just posting on website? Social shares? Including it as a link in another asset? Sending along in sales email cadences?
• What's the ultimate objective of the blog? What's the big CTA?
• Is there opportunity to refresh an older blog that was high-performing?
I have some thoughts about larger content marketing strat, specifically how content strat tends to be big developers and advocates of brand, but this is blog-specific. Good luck!

Some of this stuff may be included as subpoints within the points you mentioned, but when it comes to blogs, specifically, here are some other items we think about when planning and drafting blogs:
How do blogs fit into larger marketing campaigns?
To that end, where do these blogs fit into the funnel? Most of the time, it's awareness-level, but sometimes they can go into that MOFU phase.
Where/how will we promote the blogs (just posting on website? Social shares? Including it as a link in another asset? Sending along in sales email cadences?
What's the ultimate objective of the blog? What's the big CTA?
Is there opportunity to refresh an older blog that was high-performing?
I have some thoughts about larger content marketing strat, specifically how content strat tends to be big developers and advocates of brand, but this is blog-specific. Good luck!

text: I was expecting to hear the opposite - but I'm relieved you all don't think it's worth it! Hubspot had an automatic moderation queue which I really appreciated because 90% of all our comments were spam - but we wouldn't have that with WP. Thanks for the input all!

text: If you don't mind sharing, what is your strategy for your blog - and how did you develop it? I just finished up a blog prune and audit and it's making me re-evaluate everything we've done (lol). I'm trying to firm up what we actually want to use our blog for, whether it's lead generation, brand awareness, organic search growth, etc. or multiple.

elements.text: If you don't mind sharing, what is your strategy for your blog - and how did you develop it? I just finished up a blog prune and audit and it's making me re-evaluate everything we've done (lol). I'm trying to firm up what we actually want to use our blog for, whether it's lead generation, brand awareness, organic search growth, etc. or multiple.

text:
I’ve taken a very narrow approach with our blog (for now).

1. 100% of the topics are SEO focused to drive organic search growth. We’ve grown our organic traffic by almost 150% in 5 months as a result.
2. Once our DA was up, I started engaging with people for guest posts (once or twice a month) to get some more organic engagement and brand awareness on LI and Twitter.

elements.text: I’ve taken a very narrow approach with our blog (for now).
100% of the topics are SEO focused to drive organic search growth. We’ve grown our organic traffic by almost 150% in 5 months as a result.
Once our DA was up, I started engaging with people for guest posts (once or twice a month) to get some more organic engagement and brand awareness on LI and Twitter.

text: It depends on the business that the blog supports. There are businesses where there is no long-term relationship with the customer (like, say, a mattress company) where you’d want to attract and convert traffic ASAP. There are other businesses (monthly subscriptions) where building a dedicated audience (and maybe even a community) is more of the aim.

text: Hey everyone! I'm in the process of putting together a blog post and curious if anyone here has gone through a disavow process with backlinks before? If so, I'd love to hear about your experiences and any insights you could share!

elements.text: Hey everyone! I'm in the process of putting together a blog post and curious if anyone here has gone through a disavow process with backlinks before? If so, I'd love to hear about your experiences and any insights you could share!

text: following :eyes:

elements.text: following

text:
Love this question – there are really two main approaches to the disavow process. Doing it proactively and doing it reactively. 

Typically proactive is the way to go with everything, but in this particular case, Google is incredibly smart at understanding links so unless you are affected by a significant amount of spam that you spot before Google, I wouldn’t worry too much about them (they no longer demote the site when they find toxic links anyway, Gary Ilyes – hope that’s the right spelling – said this a while ago, they now just devalue the links unless you get a manual penalty). 

Then the other approach is to manually review the links that your site is earning and update your disavow file as you go to reduce the risk of your site ever being affected so that you never have to worry that the day will come when your site is suddenly affected. 

In my experience, unless you’re knowingly doing something that is against their guidelines disavow files aren’t something you have to worry about in most situations. Especially if you have a high authority domain that naturally attracts a lot of links when it is published, as long as the link profile is diverse and the majority isn’t spam, the need to disavow individually has never really presented itself. Interested to see what others contribute to that article though so please do post the link here :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:

In my experience, unless you’re knowingly doing something that is against their guidelines disavow files aren’t something you have to worry about in most situations. text: TL;DR of the above: Personally, I rarely ever disavow – I haven’t for any of my agency’s clients (though I have worked with businesses that have done so in the past).

elements.text: TL;DR of the above: Personally, I rarely ever disavow – I haven’t for any of my agency’s clients (though I have worked with businesses that have done so in the past).

text:
Nothing really to add to the above. I’ve disavowed once for Wiza since one site was adding 500+ backlinks (repeating across all pages).

For another client, I would go through once a month and disavow any particularly sketchy domains. Maybe 3-4 a month.

text: For organic search and awareness, I use content clusters based on the specific and more general queries a target audience is searching. And include high-value opt-ins to generate leads.

text: Official Google guidance essentially boils down to “the vast majority of sites don’t have to worry about disavow”

text:
Used to do an insane amount of penalty recoveries/disavows back in the day.

As Alex mentioned, not as relevant nowadays unless you get a manual penalty and even then, you can do a mini-disavow to show them how _proactive_ you’ve been.

Happy to dive in deeper via DM

text: Thanks - this is all very helpful. I am curious - does anyone use their blog in this way - and why, or why not? _Scenario_: Write a long-form content piece. Then write 3-4 blog posts (or split up long content piece into posts) to promote the long-form content piece and get downloads.

elements.text: Thanks - this is all very helpful. I am curious - does anyone use their blog in this way - and why, or why not?
Scenario
: Write a long-form content piece. Then write 3-4 blog posts (or split up long content piece into posts) to promote the long-form content piece and get downloads.

text: Hi all! Has anyone ever hired contractors off of UpWork or something similar to fix some site issues that are hurting your SEO? We have thousands of images that need to be resized, broken links, and hundreds of old blogs I'd like to retire - but I've never hired outsiders for something like this.

elements.text: Hi all! Has anyone ever hired contractors off of UpWork or something similar to fix some site issues that are hurting your SEO? We have thousands of images that need to be resized, broken links, and hundreds of old blogs I'd like to retire - but I've never hired outsiders for something like this.

text: No, but I have had (paid) interns focus on this for a significant portion of their time. Maybe like 50% this, 50% actual content creation so their brains don’t turn to mush.

elements.text: No, but I have had (paid) interns focus on this for a significant portion of their time. Maybe like 50% this, 50% actual content creation so their brains don’t turn to mush.

text: There are some GREAT folks on Upwork, but you really want to vet people. If you're going to hire a freelancer for very specific tasks like that, I'd recommend having strong SOPs you can leverage.

elements.text: There are some GREAT folks on Upwork, but you really want to vet people. If you're going to hire a freelancer for very specific tasks like that, I'd recommend having strong SOPs you can leverage.

text:
That’s interesting Elizabeth, we do it the other way around. We don’t write blog posts with the aim to promote the long form content piece; rather, we write blog posts that target high search volume keywords, then promote relevant long form pieces on those posts that are related to the their topics. 

TL; DR - We start with writing content that will get people to our site, then see what we can promote that’s related to that post to get their contact info.
